questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not use ionizing radiation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) FAST

 

Option B:

 

FAST stands for Focussed Assessment Sonography in Trauma. FAST is an ultrasound-based investigation; it does not use ionizing radiation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Scintigraphy is a diagnostic test that uses ionizing gamma rays to create two-dimensional images.

 

Option C: Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) is a type of X-ray that uses iodinated contrast and ionizing radiation to visualize the urinary tract.

 

Option D: Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is an imaging technique using ionizing X-rays to view blood vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is an ultrasound-based diagnostic method that does not use ionizing radiation, making it a safe and non-invasive choice for evaluating patients with potential injuries.

choices.text: Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography
Simple Photon Emission Computed Tomography
Single Proton Emission Computed Tomography
Single Positron Emission Computed Tomography

questions.text: What does the acronym SPECT stand for in medical imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography

 

Option A:

 

Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is a type of nuclear medicine test, that uses gamma rays and is a hybrid imaging with CT to provide 3D images.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect pair of maximum radiation exposure limit according to AERB:
Choices:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occupational pregnant female worker – 1 mSv/yr.

 

Explanation:

 

Maximum Permissible Dose

 

 

Educational Objective: 
 

The maximum dose for occupational pregnant female workers is 2 mSv/yr.

choices.text: Refer to ethics board
Termination of pregnancy

questions.text: At 7 weeks of pregnancy, a pregnant woman was accidentally exposed to an X-ray. What advice do you have for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Continue pregnancy.

 

Option C:

 

Diagnostic imaging studies typically expose the fetus to less than 50 mGy/5 rads, and there is no evidence that ionizing radiation at this dose level increases the risk of fetal anomalies, intellectual disability, growth restriction, or pregnancy loss.

 

During the first 14 days after conception, the fetus is most vulnerable to the lethal effects of ionizing radiation. During this time, the radiation-exposed pregnancy either survives unharmed or is resorbed (termed as "all or none"). Because of the pluripotent nature of each cell in the very early embryo, radiation-induced teratogenesis, growth restriction, or carcinogenesis are not observed during this stage of development. The embryo may be damaged during organogenesis (2 to 8 weeks POG) as a result of radiation-induced cell death, resulting in foetal growth restriction and congenital malformations. The most common manifestation of radiation injury in utero is microcephaly.

 

Most diagnostic imaging studies expose the fetus to less than 50 mGy, which is not associated with an increased risk of fetal anomalies or pregnancy loss.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: While ethical considerations are important in managing accidental exposures, the ethics board does not provide medical management.

 

Option B: This is an extreme measure and is not recommended solely based on exposure to the typically low levels of radiation from diagnostic imaging.

 

Option D: While karyotyping can identify chromosomal anomalies, it is not indicated in this context without evidence of significant radiation exposure or other risk factors.

 

Educational objective:

 

In the case of accidental exposure to X-rays at 7 weeks of pregnancy, the recommended advice is to continue the pregnancy as diagnostic imaging studies usually expose the fetus to a dose of radiation that is not associated with an increased risk of anomalies or pregnancy loss.

questions.text: Which of the following does not fall under ionizing radiations?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiofrequency waves

 

Option C:

 

MRI is a technique that produces topographic images using magnetic fields and radiofrequency waves.

 

The ionizing radiations and particles include:

 

  • Alpha
  • Beta
  • Protons
  • Gamma
  • X-Rays

 

Radiofrequency waves are a type of non-ionizing radiation. They are used in various applications, including telecommunications and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), where they excite the magnetic properties of atoms rather than ionizing the material through which they pass

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Beta rays are high-energy, high-speed electrons emitted by certain types of radioactive nuclei. They are a form of ionizing radiation and can cause ionization in the materials they pass through.

 

Option B: X-rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation with a wavelength in the range of 0.01 to 10 nanometers, corresponding to frequencies in the range 30 petahertz to 30 exahertz. X-rays are known for their use in medical imaging and as ionizing radiation, they have the ability to ionize atoms and disrupt molecular bonds, which can cause cellular damage.

 

Option D: Alpha rays consist of alpha particles, which are helium nuclei, and are another type of ionizing radiation emitted by radioactive materials. Alpha particles are generally less penetrating than beta particles and gamma rays because they are larger and carry a double positive charge, which causes intense ionization along a very short path.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiofrequency waves, used in MRI, do not cause ionization and therefore do not fall under the category of ionizing radiations unlike beta rays, X-rays, and alpha rays.

questions.text: A person has an injury in the forefinger with glass and it is suspected that he has a retained piece of glass in his finger. What is the first investigation you will do?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Plain radiograph

 

Option D.

 

A plain radiograph is the first-line investigation for a suspected foreign body like glass due to its availability, quick results, and efficiency in detecting radiopaque materials.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CT scan, while detailed, is not the first choice for foreign bodies due to its higher cost and radiation exposure compared X-ray.

 

Option B. MRI is contraindicated as the first investigation for suspected glass in the finger due to the risk of the material being ferromagnetic and potentially causing harm.

 

Option C. Ultrasonography can be useful for detecting soft tissue foreign bodies but may not be as effective as other modalities for identifying glass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first investigation for a retained piece of glass in the finger is a plain radiograph, due to its effectiveness in identifying radiopaque objects and immediate availability.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 642

choices.text: MDCT offers a better 3D reconstruction
The higher the pitch, the lower will be the CT quality
Helical CT is faster than non-helical CT
The higher the pitch, the higher will be the radiation dose

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true statement about CT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Higher the pitch, the higher will be the radiation dose

 

Option D.

 

A higher pitch generally leads to lower radiation exposure because the X-ray source covers more area in less time, reducing the amount of radiation needed.

 

CT pitch is a term used in computed tomography (CT) to describe the relative speed of the CT scanner's table movement to the width of the X-ray beam.

 

It is defined as the ratio of the distance travelled by the CT table during one rotation of the X-ray tube to the width of the X-ray beam.

 

Pitch: Table movement per rotation/slice thickness

 

A higher pitch value indicates that the table moves faster during the scan, while a lower pitch value indicates a slower table movement. This affects the speed of image acquisition, with higher pitch values allowing for faster scans but potentially sacrificing image quality due to increased image noise or artifacts. Lower pitch values, on the other hand, provide higher image quality but may result in longer scan times.

 

Pitch α 1 /quality

α 1/ dose

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MDCT offers a better 3D reconstruction. Multidetector CT (MDCT) allows for faster data acquisition and finer spatial resolution, facilitating superior 3D reconstruction of images.

 

Option B. The higher the pitch, the lower will be the CT quality. Increasing the pitch, which refers to the table movement speed relative to the X-ray beam's width, an lead to decreased image quality due to potential artifacts and increased noise.

 

Option C. Helical CT is faster than non-helical CT. Helical (spiral) CT uses continuous data acquisition as the patient moves through the scanner, leading to quicker scans compared to the step-and-shoot approach of non-helical CT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A higher pitch in CT scanning correlates with a faster table movement and typically results in a lower radiation dose to the patient, contrary to the notion that it increases dose exposure.

 

 

 

Figure 1 CT Scanner

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 928

questions.text: The walls of the CT scanner rooms are coated with which of the following compounds:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lead

 

Option C.

 

Lead is commonly used for radiation shielding in medical facilities due to its high density and effectiveness in absorbing various types of ionizing radiation.

 

CT scanners produce a significant amount of radiation, and to ensure the safety of personnel and patients, the walls of CT scanner rooms are coated with lead or other radiation-absorbing materials.

 

Lead is a particularly effective material for radiation shielding due to its high density and atomic number, which enables it to effectively absorb ionizing radiation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tungsten. Although tungsten has high density and atomic number suitable for radiation shielding, it is not commonly used for structural shielding due to its cost and practicality.

 

Option B. Iron. Iron, while dense, is not typically used for shielding CT scanner rooms because it is not as effective as lead in absorbing radiation.

 

Option D. Glass. Standard glass is not an effective material for radiation shielding; specialized leaded glass may be used in some settings but not typically for room coatings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead is used to coat the walls of CT scanner rooms as it effectively absorbs ionizing radiation, providing essential protection in medical imaging facilities.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018),page 222

questions.text: According to recent guidelines, Spiral CT is recommended in children due to decreased radiation exposure. Which of the following is the most essential element that allows acquisition in a spiral mode?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Slip ring

 

Option A.

 

In spiral CT, slip rings are an important component of the gantry. The gantry rotates continuously around the patient during the CT scan, acquiring a spiral or helical dataset of the patient's anatomy. The slip rings enable the transfer of power and data signals between the stationary and rotating parts of the gantry.

 

Overall, slip rings play an important role in enabling the continuous, spiral acquisition mode used in modern CT scanners, which allows for faster and more efficient scanning while minimizing patient radiation exposure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Faraday cage. A Faraday cage is used to block external electromagnetic fields; it's not specifically involved in spiral CT acquisition.

 

Option C. Quenching elements. Quenching elements are used in MRI systems to rapidly dissipate energy from the superconducting magnet, unrelated to CT scanning.

 

Option D. Circular gantry. While a circular gantry is part of the CT scanner's architecture, it does not specifically enable spiral scanning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Slip rings are integral to spiral CT scanners, enabling continuous rotation of the gantry during scanning, which facilitates the acquisition of helical data and reduces radiation exposure to the patient.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 916

choices.text: PET scan

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with severe chest and back pain that started suddenly. He describes the pain as sharp and tearing and rates it as 10/10 in intensity. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg, heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and he appears to be in distress. What initial investigation will you perform?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) CTA

 

Given his symptoms and history, an aortic dissection is suspected. CT angiography is investigation of choice for aortic dissection as it is more widely available and takes a shorter time when compared to MRI.
 

MRI, being time-consuming, is indicated in cases of severe renal insufficiency or when the use of an iodinated contrast medium is contraindicated.

choices.text: To detect ischemic changes in the brain tissue
To identify the location where reperfusion will be beneficial
To visualize the cerebral vasculature
To evaluate the presence of hemorrhage in the brain

questions.text: What is the main purpose of CT perfusion imaging in stroke diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B. To identify the location where reperfusion will be beneficial

 

CT perfusion penumbra refers to the area of brain tissue surrounding a stroke that is at risk of infarct if blood flow is not restored quickly. The term "penumbra" is used because this area is not completely infarcted yet but is at risk of becoming irreversibly damaged if blood flow is not restored. Physiological parameters of blood flow e.g. blood volume, mean transit time etc. can be calculated.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with a history of blurred vision and eye pain in her left eye for the past few months. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes a pigmented lesion on the iris with irregular borders and a raised appearance. The pupil is slightly distorted, and there is mild dilation of the pupil. The intraocular pressure is within normal limits. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. A T1 weighted MRI is shown here. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Melanoma

 

Option C:

 

Melanoma: The MRI shows a T1 hyperintense intra-ocular lesion with associated subretinal effusion. In this patient's age group, the most likely differentials are Metastases and Melanoma. Melanin has a characteristic T1 hyperintensity, making Melanoma the most probable diagnosis given the patient’s clinical presentation and imaging findings.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Metastasis: While metastases can appear similar on imaging, they are less likely to exhibit the T1 hyperintense signal characteristic of melanin.

 

Option B. PHPV (Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous): This condition is typically diagnosed in infants, not adults, and is associated with a congenitally malformed eye rather than an acquired lesion.

 

Option D. Retinoblastoma: This is a childhood tumor and would be exceedingly rare in a 60-year-old patient. Also, it usually doesn't present with pigmented lesions on the iris.

 

Educational objective:

 

In an adult patient presenting with pigmented lesions of the iris and characteristic T1 hyperintensity on MRI, melanoma is a key differential to consider, especially when the lesion shows subretinal effusion and features suggestive of melanin.

questions.text: All of the following are correctly paired with HU on CT except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fat: 0-20

 

Option A.

 

Fat: 0-20. Typically, fat has a negative HU value, usually ranging from -80 to -100 HU, not 0-20 as listed.

 

Hounsfield Units, also known as CT numbers, which are used to measure the density of a particular tissue or material.

 

HU values are determined by measuring the linear attenuation of X-rays as they pass through the body and are detected by the CT scanner.

 

Materials with a higher density than water, such as bone or metal, have positive HU values, while materials with lower density, such as fat or air, have negative HU values.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Contrast: 130. Iodinated contrast material used in CT imaging generally appears bright with HU around 130, which is a correct pairing.

 

Option C. Acute hemorrhage: 60-70. Acute blood can be identified on a CT scan within this HU range, making this pairing correct.

 

Option D. Calcification: 800-1000. Calcifications are dense materials that have high HU values within the range of 800-1000, correctly paired here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct Hounsfield Unit (HU) range for fat on a CT scan is typically negative, between -80 to -100 HU, not 0-20 as incorrectly stated.

 

HU values:

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 6

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of smoking and hypertension presents to the emergency department with sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain. She also reports feeling lightheaded and dizzy. On physical examination, her respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg. There is edema of the right lower limb. Which is the best investigation for the given clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. CECT

 

Option A.

 

CECT, specifically CT pulmonary angiography, is the preferred test for detecting pulmonary embolism due to its high sensitivity and specificity for showing vascular filling defects.

 

Given her symptoms and risk factors, a pulmonary embolism is suspected. A CT pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) is ordered, which reveals a filling defect in the left main pulmonary artery, confirming the diagnosis of a pulmonary embolism. It is a CECT which is acquired in the early arterial phase to ensure maximum contrast density in the pulmonary artery.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. HRCT (High-Resolution Computed Tomography). HRCT is excellent for detailed lung parenchyma imaging but is not the first choice for suspected pulmonary embolism.

 

Option C. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging). MRI is less commonly used in acute settings due to longer scan times and is not the investigation of choice for pulmonary embolism.

 

Option D. V/Q scan (Ventilation/Perfusion scan). A V/Q scan is an alternative when CTPA is contraindicated, but CECT is superior in diagnostic accuracy for pulmonary embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with risk factors for thromboembolic disease presenting with sudden respiratory symptoms and unilateral edema, CECT, particularly CT pulmonary angiography, is the best investigation to confirm a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism.

 

 

Figure 7 CTPA showing massive saddle embolus in main pulmonary artery

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 140

questions.text: Which type of ultrasound transducer is depicted in the image provided?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Phased array

 

Option A:

 

Commonly used for cardiac imaging due to its small footprint and ability to steer the ultrasound beam electronically.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Curvilinear – Typically utilized for abdominal and pelvic imaging, it has a low frequency that allows for greater penetration depth.

 

Option C. Endoscopic US – Designed for insertion into body cavities, often with higher frequencies for fine details.

 

Option D. Endo-cavitary – Similar to endoscopic but specifically designed for cavities like rectal or vaginal imaging, often seen in transvaginal or transrectal ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phased array or sectoral transducer shown is ideal for transthoracic echocardiography due to its ability to provide a wide field of view in a small acoustic window.

 

Phased array/Sectoral probe used for transthoracic ECHO is shown here.

 

 

Ref: Page no-196, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

questions.text: The earliest sign of portal hypertension is change in portal venous flow to hepatofugal flow. What is the best investigation to detect this?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Color Doppler

 

Option B.

 

The doppler effect results from an apparent shift in sound frequency as sound waves are reflected from moving targets, usually blood cells. In color doppler, the type of color represents the direction of flow.

 

Red - flow is towards the transducer

 

Blue - flows is away from the transducer

 

 

Color Doppler USG visualizes blood flow, including direction and velocity, which is crucial for assessing portal hypertension.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. B-mode USG provides two-dimensional grayscale images of tissues and organs but does not show blood flow direction.

 

Option C. M-Mode USG captures moving structures and their motion over time but is not ideal for blood flow direction.

 

Option D. A-Mode USG provides a one-dimensional view of reflected sound waves, insufficient for flow evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Color Doppler ultrasonography is the best modality for detecting changes in portal venous flow, such as those seen in early portal hypertension, due to its ability to show the direction and velocity of blood flow.

 

Ref: Page no-162, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by ambulance following a motor vehicle accident. On arrival, the patient is alert and oriented but appears in distress and complaining of severe abdominal pain. He has multiple abrasions and contusions on his chest and abdomen. His vital signs are stable except for a mildly elevated heart rate. The trauma team initiates an extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (e-FAST) as given below. What will be your interpretation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fast positive

 

Option B:

 

In the image given in the question, anechoic fluid is seen between the liver and kidney (the hepatorenal pouch of Morrison), which is suggestive of hemoperitoneum in a trauma setting.

 

(FAST positive) indicates the presence of free fluid, such as blood, in the abdominal cavity. Given the clinical context and the ultrasound findings of anechoic fluid in the hepatorenal pouch, this is the correct interpretation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: FAST negative would indicate no evidence of free fluid or other abnormalities on the ultrasound, which is not consistent with the presence of anechoic fluid seen in the image.

 

Option C: FAST inconclusive would suggest that the ultrasound results are uncertain or difficult to interpret, which is not the case here given the clear visualization of fluid.

 

Option D: Fast is incomplete as it stands for Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma, but without specifying whether it is positive, negative, or inconclusive, it does not represent an answer to the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct interpretation of the e-FAST in this clinical scenario is FAST positive, indicative of a hemoperitoneum due to the visualization of anechoic fluid in the hepatorenal pouch, which is consistent with hemoperitoneum in a trauma patient.

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior vena cava

 

Option B:

 

The structure marked as 'A' in the CT thorax is the superior vena cava.

Superior Vena Cava The SVC is located in the anterior right superior mediastinum, which is consistent with the location of the structure marked in the image.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Descending Aorta: The descending aorta typically lies posteriorly in the mediastinum and would not be located in the position marked in the provided CT image.

 

Option C. Ascending Aorta: The ascending aorta would generally be seen slightly leftward in the mediastinal space in a CT scan. It should appear as a prominent, rounded structure due to the flow of contrast within it.

 

Option D. Right Pulmonary Artery: The right pulmonary artery on CT scan, is usually located anterior to the descending aorta and to the left of the ascending aorta and SVC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 216

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with acute onset shortness of breath following a motor vehicle accident. On examination, decreased breath sounds are noted on the left side. Bedside ultrasonography is performed, and the image shown is obtained using M-mode. Which of the following signs is most likely being depicted in this ultrasound image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Seashore sign

 

Option A:

 

In M-mode ultrasound, this sign indicates normal lung sliding, where there is motion between the visceral and parietal pleura. On the monitor, above the pleural line, motionless chest wall soft tissue creates a pattern resembling static waves, while the granular appearance below the pleural line is created by the sliding lung, resembling the sandy texture of a seashore.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Stratosphere sign: Also known as the barcode sign, this pattern is seen in M-mode when lung sliding is absent, such as in pneumothorax. It's characterized by parallel lines above and below the pleural line, resembling a barcode or a stratospheric pattern, without the sandy appearance of lung sliding.

 

Option C. Lung point sign: This sign is specific for pneumothorax in B-mode ultrasonography. It is the point at which the normal seashore sign and the abnormal stratosphere sign meet, indicating the presence of both lung tissue and the air of a pneumothorax side by side.

 

Option D. Sinusoidal sign: This sign is indicative of a 'flapping' motion of the heart or the IVC in M-mode and is typically associated with cardiac pathologies like pericardial effusion or exaggerated IVC collapsibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The seashore sign on M-mode ultrasonography is indicative of normal lung sliding, seen at the pleural lining due to relative motion between the two pleural layers. This is the M-mode counterpart of lung sliding seen in B-mode ultrasound, where motion of the lung deep to the pleura causes a grainy appearance, simulating the appearance of sand at a seashore.

 

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 14

questions.text: How is the venous blood flow in the lower limbs characterized on Doppler ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Monophasic

 

Option D.

 

Signifies a single-phase flow pattern without respiratory variation, commonly seen in venous blood flow.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Non-phasic - This term would imply a lack of variation with respiration, which is not typical for venous flow.

 

Option B. Triphasic - Reflects a flow pattern often associated with arterial blood flow, not venous.

 

Option C. Biphasic - Indicates two phases in the blood flow cycle, also more typical of arterial flow.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Venous blood flow in the lower limbs is typically monophasic on Doppler ultrasound, characterized by a continuous, non-varying flow that does not change with respiration.

 

 

Ref: Page no-212, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

questions.text: Identify the radiological procedure shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Enteroclysis

 

Option A:

 

Enteroclysis is a specialized radiological examination where barium is introduced directly into the small intestine via a tube to distend and evaluate it.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Proctography: A radiological test that assesses the rectal and anal function during defecation.

 

Option C. Barium enema: A barium contrast study of the large intestine that does not involve the small intestine as primarily visualized in the image.

 

Option D. Barium meal follow-through: Involves oral ingestion of barium followed by sequential X-ray imaging to track its passage through the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The image is characteristic of enteroclysis, where a tube is inserted up to the duodenojejunal flexure, and barium is injected to provide enhanced distension and visualization of the small bowel.


Barium enteroclysis is performed via a tube inserted up to DJ flexure and barium is injected to provide better distension.

 

 

Ref: Page no-276, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: What is the common name of this view shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Caldwell view

 

Option B:

 

The above X ray shows the Caldwell view in which the frontal sinus is best seen.

 

Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view). The view is taken with nose and forehead touching the film and X-ray beam is projected 15–20°caudally.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Water's view: Used primarily to visualize the maxillary sinuses, the patient's head is tilted back about 45 degrees so the maxillary sinuses are projected below the petrous ridge.

 

Option C. Pierre's view: This is not a standard radiographic view; it may be confused with Stenvers or Pirie's view, which are used for different purposes.

 

Option D. Towne's view: This view is used to visualize the occipital bone, posterior fossa, and foramen magnum. The X-ray beam is angled 30 degrees caudally to the orbitomeatal line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Caldwell view is an occipitofrontal radiographic projection that optimally demonstrates the frontal sinuses. It is obtained with the patient's forehead and nose resting on the X-ray cassette and the central beam directed caudally.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 858

choices.text: Maximum radiation exposure
Best for bone cortical lesions
IOC for interstitial lung disease
Best contrast resolution

questions.text: All are false statements regarding MRI except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Best contrast resolution

 

Option D:

 

MRI is known for its excellent contrast resolution, which allows for clear visualization of soft tissues, organs, and structures within the body. This is due to the different magnetic properties of different tissues, which are detected by the MRI machine and converted into images with excellent contrast.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) does not use ionizing radiation.

 

Option B. MRI is not the best imaging modality for detecting bone abnormalities in the cortical bone. MRI is the best for detecting bone marrow lesions.

 

Option C. High-resolution CT (HRCT) is considered the imaging modality of choice for evaluating interstitial lung disease due to its superior ability to visualize the lung parenchyma and detect abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI is a valuable diagnostic tool that offers excellent contrast resolution without the use of ionizing radiation, making it ideal for evaluating soft tissue contrasts in various medical conditions.

choices.text: Severity of effect is a function of dose
Probability of effect is a function of dose

questions.text: All of the following statements about “Stochastic effects” of radiation are false except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Probability of effect is a function of dose

 

Option D:

 

Stochastic effects of radiation are those that occur by chance, without a threshold dose, and the probability of occurrence increases with the dose. These effects, such as cancer or genetic mutations, do not have a severity that increases with dose; rather, only the likelihood of the effect occurring does.

 

This is true for stochastic effects. The likelihood of occurrence, such as cancer or genetic mutations, increases with the dose, but not the severity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Stochastic effects, by definition, do not have a threshold; they can occur at any level of radiation exposure.

 

Option B: This statement is more aligned with deterministic effects, where severity increases with the dose.

 

Option C: These are examples of deterministic effects, not stochastic ones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stochastic effects of radiation are characterized by the lack of a threshold and the fact that the probability, not the severity, of effects such as cancer or genetic mutations is proportional to the dose.

 

Probability being a function of dose is true for stochastic effects, such as cancer.

choices.text: T1 weighted image
T2 weighted image

questions.text: Identify the MRI image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. T1 weighted image

 

Option C:

 

T1-weighted images are excellent for visualizing anatomy and are commonly used for detecting abnormalities in the brain, such as atrophy or structural anomalies.

 

The image provided appears to be a T1-weighted MRI of the brain. In T1-weighted images, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is typically dark or hypointense, whereas white matter is hyperintense or bright, and gray matter is intermediate in intensity or dark. One distinguishing feature on T1-weighted images is the high signal intensity from the posterior pituitary, often referred to as the "pituitary bright spot," which is usually seen as a bright signal on T1 due to the presence of vasopressin within the neurosecretory granules.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. FLAIR (Fluid Attenuated Inversion Recovery) sequences are used to null the fluid signals, which helps in identifying periventricular lesions, such as those seen in multiple sclerosis, as the CSF appears dark, providing a good contrast against hyperintense lesions.

 

Option B. STIR (Short Tau Inversion Recovery) images are used to null fat signals, making them helpful in detecting lesions in the musculoskeletal system, particularly within the bone marrow.

 

Option D. T2-weighted images show CSF as hyperintense or bright and are valuable in detecting edema, inflammation, and certain types of lesions within the brain tissue.

 

Educational objective:

 

In T1-weighted MRI CSF appears dark, white matter is bright, and gray matter is dark. The presence of the "pituitary bright spot" is a key indicator that the image is T1-weighted.

choices.text: MRI Contrast-enhanced angiography

questions.text: Which of the following techniques can be used to visualize the vessels in a patient with renal failure?
questions.solution:
Ans: C) Time of Flight Angiography

 

Option C:

 

For patients with renal failure who need vascular imaging, contrast agents typically used in CT angiography and MRI contrast-enhanced angiography may pose a risk due to the potential for contrast-induced nephropathy or nephrogenic systemic fibrosis. Therefore, alternative imaging techniques that do not require contrast agents are preferred.

Time-of-flight (TOF) angiography is a non-contrast MRI technique that uses the flow of blood itself to create an image of the blood vessels. It is especially useful for patients with renal impairment because it does not require gadolinium-based contrast agents, which are contraindicated for patients with severe renal failure due to the risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CT angiography typically uses iodinated contrast, which is contraindicated in patients with renal failure due to the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy.

 

Option B. MRI Contrast-enhanced angiography requires the use of gadolinium-based contrast agents, which are contraindicated in patients with significant renal failure.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) also uses iodinated contrast and poses similar risks as CT angiography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Time-of-flight (TOF) angiography is the preferred technique for visualizing vessels in patients with renal failure as it does not require contrast agents and reduces the risk of further kidney damage.

questions.text: What is the principle behind Functional MRI done for a patient undergoing neurosurg ery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. BOLD Technique

 

Option B:

 

Functional MRI (fMRI) is a non-invasive neuroimaging technique that measures and maps brain activity. The principle behind fMRI is the BOLD (Blood Oxygenation Level Dependent) technique. Here's how it works:

 

BOLD technique: The BOLD technique is based on the physiological fact that active neurons in the brain require more oxygen. When a brain region is active, the increase in neural activity is accompanied by an increased demand for oxygen, leading to a localized increase in blood flow to that region. The hemoglobin in this blood has different magnetic properties depending on whether it's oxygenated or deoxygenated. Oxygenated hemoglobin (oxyHb) is less magnetic (diamagnetic) than deoxygenated hemoglobin (deoxyHb), which is more magnetic (paramagnetic). fMRI machines detect these subtle changes in the brain's blood flow and oxygenation levels, which indirectly reflect neural activity.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Brownian motion: This refers to the random movement of particles suspended in a fluid. While this phenomenon is an important aspect of diffusion-weighted imaging in MRI, it is not used in fMRI.

 

Option C. Tissue attenuation: This is a concept more commonly associated with ultrasound or CT imaging, referring to the reduction in signal strength as it passes through different tissues. This is not related to fMRI.

 

Option D. Pulse echo: This is a technique used in conventional MRI to generate images by emitting a pulse of radio waves and then detecting the echoes that result from the relaxation of protons in the magnetic field. This is different from the BOLD technique used in fMRI.

 

Educational objective:

 

The BOLD technique is the foundation of fMRI and is based on the differing magnetic properties of oxygenated and deoxygenated hemoglobin, providing a means of measuring and mapping brain activity through changes in blood oxygenation and flow.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions show Diffusion-Restriction? 

 

1. Arachnoid cyst       

2. Epidermoid cyst

3. Acute infarct

4. Brain abscess
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Diffusion-weighted (DWI) MRI

 

            

                 DWI                                              ADC Map

 

Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) allows us to assess the random Brownian motion of water molecules within tissue. When this motion is hindered or 'restricted', it can indicate pathology.

 

  1. Arachnoid cyst: These are CSF-filled spaces and typically do not restrict diffusion, meaning they would appear hypointense or similar to CSF on DWI and hyperintense on ADC (Apparent Diffusion Coefficient) maps, just like normal CSF.
  2. Epidermoid cyst: These cysts are filled with keratin, a protein that restricts the diffusion of water molecules. Therefore, they appear hyperintense on DWI and hypointense on ADC maps, indicating restricted diffusion.
  3. Acute infarct: Shortly after a stroke, the affected brain tissue shows cytotoxic edema where cells swell, restricting water molecule movement. Hence, an acute infarct will appear hyperintense on DWI and hypointense on ADC maps.
  4. Brain abscess: The pus within an abscess restricts water movement due to the high cellular content and debris. Thus, abscesses show restricted diffusion, appearing hyperintense on DWI and hypointense on ADC maps.

The correct option that includes conditions showing diffusion restriction is:

 

C) 2, 3, 4: Epidermoid cyst, acute infarct, and brain abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of DWI MRI, diffusion restriction, seen as hyperintensity on DWI and corresponding hypointensity on ADC maps, is typically associated with pathology such as epidermoid cysts, acute infarcts, and brain abscesses, but not arachnoid cysts.

questions.text:
What medical conditions are associated with posterior acoustic shadowing in ultrasound imaging?

 

  1. Air
  2. Bone
  3. Renal stones
  4. Uterine fibroids
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

Posterior acoustic shadowing refers to the dark area that appears behind an object in an ultrasound image. This shadow is created when the sound waves produced by the ultrasound machine are blocked or absorbed by an object, such as a dense tissue or a calcification, and cannot pass through it.

 

Includes air, bone, renal stones, and uterine fibroids. All these elements can cause posterior acoustic shadowing due to their high density or composition, which prevents ultrasound waves from passing through, casting a shadow on the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior acoustic shadowing is observed in the presence of air, bone, renal stones, and uterine fibroids as they are highly reflective or absorbent to ultrasound waves, preventing wave transmission and resulting in a shadow on the ultrasound image.

 

 

Ref: Page no-445, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

choices.text: Treatment of coronary artery disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not a utility of ultrasound imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Treatment of coronary artery disease

 

Option C.

 

There is no established use of ultrasound in treatment of coronary artery disease. Stenting is performed for symptomatic coronary artery occlusion and is done using Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA), not ultrasound.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ultrasound is useful to evaluate diaphragmatic function due to its real-time imaging capability.

 

Option B. Extended Focused assessment with sonography for Trauma (EFAST) is used for evaluation of hemoperitoneum, hemopericardium, hemothorax, pneumothorax and intravascular filling status.

 

Option D: USG is useful for guiding central line insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ultrasound imaging does not have an established role in the treatment of coronary artery disease; procedures like stenting for symptomatic coronary occlusion are performed using Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA).

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

choices.text: Has therapeutic potential useful to treat fibroids
Thromboelastography is a form of USG elastography
Fibro scan is non-invasive estimation of liver cirrhosis
EUS is best to estimate T-staging of carcinoma esophagus

questions.text: All of the following are true about ultrasound except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thromboelastography is a form of USG elastography

 

Option B.

 

Thromboelastography (TEG) provides a functional assay of clotting and clot lysis that can be used to guide resuscitation and treatment efforts. There are three phases of coagulation that are measured with TEG: clot initiation, clot strength, and clot stability. It is not a type of USG elastography.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HIFU (high intensity focused US) is a therapeutic application of US. It is useful for the treatment of fibroids. HIFU exploits the thermal effects of high-powered tightly-focused ultrasound beams so that very small target tissues can be heated and coagulated.

 

Option C. Fibro scan = transient elastography; Used for non-invasive investigation for liver cirrhosis

 

Option D. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is the best modality for T-staging of GI malignances (particularly esophageal malignances)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thromboelastography (TEG) is not a form of ultrasound elastography; it is a diagnostic test that evaluates the clotting process of blood.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

questions.text: Identify the mode in USG:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. M mode

 

Option A.

 

The US image represents M-mode used for Fetal heart rate evaluation and pneumothorax.

 

M mode is often used for evaluating cardiac motion and valvular structures, providing a one-dimensional view over time.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Doppler – Used to measure the velocity and direction of blood flow within the body.

 

Option C. A mode – Provides amplitude modulation, useful in ophthalmology for eye examinations.

 

Option D. B mode – The basic mode of ultrasound that gives a two-dimensional cross-sectional image of the tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The image displays M mode, a specific ultrasound mode primarily utilized for evaluating the fetal heart rate and assessing for pneumothorax by showing the motion of structures over time.

 

Modes in USG:

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Myelography

 

Option A:

 

Myelography is the process of injecting iodinated contrast medium into the subarachnoid space.

 

Contrast agent of choice: Iohexol

 

Myelography has largely been replaced by MRI and CT but it is still sometimes performed, particularly in patients with spinal hardware precluding MRI studies.

 

Myelography is an imaging technique that involves injecting contrast medium into the subarachnoid space around the spinal cord.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Neurography – Specialized MRI technique to image peripheral nerves.

 

Option C: Fluoroscopy – Real-time X-ray imaging that is often used to guide procedures.

 

Option D: Angiography – Imaging of blood vessels using contrast media.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The image demonstrates myelography, an investigation where contrast is injected into the subarachnoid space, primarily used when MRI is contraindicated.

 

Ref: Page no -812, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of peptic ulcer disease presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, distention, and vomiting for the past 24 hours. He reports that the pain started suddenly and has been getting progressively worse. He has not had a bowel movement or passed gas in over 12 hours. On examination, the patient appears to be in severe distress, with a distended and tender abdomen. He has a fever of 39°C, and his blood pressure is low at 90/60 mmHg. Blood tests show an elevated white blood cell count. Which of the following would be detrimental in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Barium meal

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of perforation secondary to intestinal obstruction. Barium studies are contraindicated in this case as they lead to aggravation of peritonitis.

 

Contraindications to barium studies:

 

  • Perforation
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Post operative bowel Surgery
  • Tracheo-esophageal fistula
  • Water soluble iodinated water contrast is preferred in all of these cases

 

Barium meal is contraindicated because if there is a perforation, barium can leak into the peritoneal cavity, leading to chemical peritonitis and exacerbating the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) can be utilized for abdominal assessment, but caution is needed regarding contrast in suspected perforation cases.

 

Option B: CECT with oral contrast may help delineate anatomy, but there's a risk if perforation is present.

 

Option C: Gastrograffin study, a water-soluble contrast study, is generally safe and can be used to identify leaks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected gastrointestinal perforation, such as with a peptic ulcer, barium contrast studies are contraindicated due to the risk of causing chemical peritonitis. Water-soluble contrast studies are preferred for their safer profile.

 

Ref: Page no -254, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe left upper quadrant (LUQ) pain after being punched by his colleague in a fight. His blood pressure is 110/76mmHg, his pulse is 80 bpm, and his respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. Which of the following will be the best investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. CT of the abdomen

 

Option D:

 

Based on the clinical presentation of severe left upper quadrant (LUQ) pain after being punched, there is a high suspicion of abdominal trauma. The patient's vital signs are relatively stable, but given the mechanism of injury, it is important to rule out any significant intra-abdominal injuries.

 

CT of the abdomen is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating abdominal trauma in stable patients.

 

CT of the abdomen provides a comprehensive evaluation of abdominal organs and structures and is the gold standard for stable patients with suspected intra-abdominal trauma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Peritoneal lavage: Previously used in the assessment of blunt abdominal trauma, now largely replaced by more advanced imaging.

 

Option B. Upper GI series: Typically used for evaluating the upper gastrointestinal tract, not for acute trauma assessment.

 

Option C. E-FAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma): A rapid bedside ultrasound examination to evaluate for free fluid and air; useful in trauma but may not be as definitive as a CT scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT of the abdomen is the preferred imaging modality for evaluating abdominal trauma in stable patients, providing detailed assessment to rule out significant internal injuries.

 

Approach to Blunt trauma abdomen

 

 

Ref: Page no-386, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, bloating, and constipation. He also reports occasional shortness of breath and chest pain. On examination, the patient has decreased breath sounds on the right side of the chest. Chest X-ray is shown here.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Chilaiditi syndrome.

 

Option B:

 

Chilaiditi syndrome is a rare condition that occurs when the colon is interposed between the liver and the right hemidiaphragm, resulting in radiographic evidence of gas-filled loops of bowel in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. It is one of the causes of pseudo pneumoperitoneum. Colonic gas in this position may be misinterpreted as true pneumoperitoneum.

 

Patients with Chilaiditi syndrome can present with recurrent abdominal pain, bloating, constipation, and occasional respiratory symptoms such as shortness of breath and chest pain. The decreased breath sounds on the right side of the chest are likely due to compression of the lung by the displaced colon.

 

Chilaiditi syndrome is the interposition of the colon between the liver and right diaphragm can cause symptoms like those described and would show elevated bowel loops on imaging.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bochdalek hernia: Typically presents at birth as a congenital defect, causing severe respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Morgagni hernia: Another type of diaphragmatic hernia, usually congenital, but less likely to cause these symptoms.

 

Option D. Large bowel obstruction: Would show dilated bowel loops and possibly air-fluid levels, but not typically associated with decreased breath sounds unless complicated by massive dilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chilaiditi syndrome is diagnosed when symptomatic interposition of the colon between the liver and diaphragm is present, as suggested by the patient's symptoms and X-ray findings.

 

Ref: Page no-392, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

choices.text: Interaction between low energy incident photon and the inner shell electron
Interaction between high energy incident photon and the inner shell electron
Interaction between low energy incident photon and the outer shell electron
Interaction of the high energy incident photon and the outer shell electron

questions.text: In diagnostic radiography, Photoelectric effect can be best described as an:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Interaction between low energy incident photon and the inner shell electron

 

Option A.

 

The photoelectric effect is a fundamental process in diagnostic radiography as it is the primary method for creating contrast in radiographs.

 

This effect occurs when an inner shell electron interacts with a low energy X-ray beam. The process involves the ejection of an inner shell electron, followed by the entrance of an outer electron into the newly vacated inner orbit, which results in the emission of additional energy as characteristic radiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The photoelectric effect in diagnostic radiography can be defined as the interaction between a low-energy incident photon and an inner shell electron, leading to the ejection of the electron and subsequent emission of characteristic radiation, crucial for creating image contrast.

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 222

questions.text: What is the composition of the focusing cup in an X-ray tube:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Nickel

 

Option B.

 

Nickel is the correct material for the focusing cup in an X-ray tube. It is chosen because it is a poor thermionic emitter, which means it doesn't contribute to the electron cloud in the tube, and it has a high melting point, making it suitable for focusing the electron beam.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tungsten is a material with a high melting point and is commonly used in X-ray tubes, specifically in the cathode and anode for its thermionic emission properties, but not typically for the focusing cup due to its thermal characteristics.

 

Option C. Lead is used in the protective housing of an X-ray tube to shield against unwanted X-ray emissions but is not suitable for the focusing cup due to its high level of X-ray absorption and lack of necessary electrical properties.

 

Option D. Aluminium is commonly used as a filter material in X-ray tubes to remove low-energy X-rays from the beam but is not used for the focusing cup due to its lower melting point and different conductive properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The focusing cup of an X-ray tube is made of nickel, due to its poor thermionic emission and high melting point, which helps in effectively focusing the electron beam towards the anode.

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018),page 222

questions.text: What are the mechanisms of heat dissipation in modern X-ray tubes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All the above

 

Option D.

 

Modern X-ray tubes utilize all these mechanisms to manage heat effectively; the circulating oil outside the vacuum tube carries away heat by conduction and convection, while radiation is the primary mode of heat loss.

 

Heat loss in the X-ray tube occurs by all modes, conduction, convection and radiation. The oil circulating outside the vacuum tube carries the heat by conduction and convection, but the main mechanism of heat loss in the modern X-ray tube is radiation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Radiation - In this process, energy is emitted from the X-ray tube in the form of electromagnetic waves, which help to dissipate heat.

 

Option B. Conduction - This refers to the transfer of heat through direct contact, such as from the X-ray tube to the surrounding oil, which conducts the heat away.

 

Option C. Convection - Heat is transferred by the movement of fluid, such as the circulating oil around the X-ray tube, which carries heat away through convection currents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heat loss in modern X-ray tubes occurs through radiation, conduction, and convection, with circulating oil playing a key role in conduction and convection, and radiation being the predominant mechanism.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 222

questions.text: A radiologist is reporting a CECT of a patient diagnosed to have a renal lesion on USG. He is inclined to make a diagnosis of right renal cyst. What is the Hounsfield number for the lesion if his diagnosis is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 0

 

Option C.

 

Distilled water, which is the reference for HU measurements, has a value of 0. A simple renal cyst, being predominantly water-filled, will also approximate this HU value.

 

HU values

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct Hounsfield Unit (HU) for a simple renal cyst on a contrast-enhanced CT scan is 0, reflecting its water-like density.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018) , page 430

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality shown in the figure:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CT

 

Option B.

 

Computed Tomography (CT) scans provide excellent detail of the cortical bone, which appears white due to high X-ray attenuation.

 

In the given images, the cortical bone is appearing white. Therefore, the images are that of a CT scan.

 

Do not confuse a CECT with a contrast/dye study. A contrast or dye study is a fluoroscopy investigation that involves the usage of iodinated contrast like HSG, IVP, and ERCP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MRI. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) does not typically depict cortical bone as white, as it uses magnetic fields and radio waves to generate images, and the cortical bone appears dark or with low signal due to lack of hydrogen atoms.

 

Option C. Angiography. This is a technique used to visualize the inside of blood vessels and organs, often using a contrast medium, but it does not provide detailed images of bone structures.

 

Option D. Contrast study. Contrast studies or fluoroscopy, such as HSG, IVP, and ERCP, involve real-time imaging with the use of iodinated contrast. They are typically used to image hollow structures or vessels, not solid structures like bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The images are from a CT scan, as evidenced by the white appearance of the cortical bone, a characteristic of CT imaging's high-resolution capability for bony structures.

 

CONTRAST STUDIES

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 429

choices.text: Provide endoluminal view
Can also be done using MRI
Colonic distension with CO2 is necessary
IOC for acute diverticulitis

questions.text: All of the following are true about the technique shown in the image below except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. IOC for acute diverticulitis

 

Option D.

 

IOC (Intraoperative Colonoscopy) for acute diverticulitis. This is not true. In the setting of acute diverticulitis, which is an inflammatory condition, virtual colonoscopy is typically contraindicated due to the risk of perforation and worsening of the condition.

 

Virtual colonoscopy is a non-invasive imaging technique that uses CT or MRI to create a 3D reconstruction of the colon, providing an endoluminal view. Optimal colonic distention is crucial for proper intraluminal evaluation of the large bowel. It is indicated for:

Screening for colorectal carcinoma

 

Evaluation of the colon after incomplete or unsuccessful conventional colonoscopy, assessment of strictures, and evaluation of the colon proximal to obstructing neoplasms detected by conventional colonoscopy

 

Patients who are unable or unwilling to undergo conventional colonoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Provides an endoluminal view. This is true as the technique visualizes the inside of the colon.

 

Option B. Can also be done using MRI. This is true; virtual colonoscopy can be performed using MRI for detailed images of soft tissue structures within the colon.

 

Option C. Colonic distension with CO2 is necessary. True, colonic distension is required to separate the walls of the colon for better visualization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Virtual colonoscopy is contraindicated in the acute phase of diverticulitis due to the risk of complications such as perforation.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 297

questions.text: Congenital Zika virus infection shows microcephaly with gray matter-white matter zone calcification. The investigation of choice to detect congenital Zika virus infection is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. NCCT

 

Option D.

 

Non-Contrast Computed Tomography (NCCT) is ideal for detecting calcifications due to its high sensitivity for variations in tissue density.


NCCT is the best investigation to detect calcification.

 

The thumb rules for NCCT are as follows:

 

  • IOC for head, spine trauma
  • IOC for acute SAH
  • IOC for intracranial calcification
  • IOC for renal calculi
  • IOC FOR IOFB
  • IOC for bone cortex
  • Initial Investigation in stroke

 

 

Calcifications seen in different infections

Cytomegalovirus – Periventricular infection

Zika virus – calcification at Grey matter-White matter junction

Toxoplasmosis – Intraparenchymal calcification

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MRI. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is highly sensitive for soft tissue contrast and brain structure anomalies but less sensitive for calcifications.

 

Option B. X-Ray. Standard X-ray imaging can detect large calcifications but lacks the sensitivity and specificity of cross-sectional imaging for detailed brain assessment.

 

Option C. CT Angiography. CT angiography is used primarily to visualize blood vessels and is not the investigation of choice for detecting brain calcifications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-Contrast Computed Tomography (NCCT) is the preferred diagnostic tool for identifying intracranial calcifications associated with congenital Zika virus infection, offering clear delineation of calcified structures within the brain.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018),page 802

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient suffered a fall from the 2nd floor. A burst fracture of L2 is suspected. What will be the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. NCCT

 

Option C.

 

NCCT is ideal for acute spine trauma, providing detailed images of bone fractures and the spinal canal.

 

NCCT is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating traumatic spine injuries. It can quickly and accurately diagnose the presence and extent of bony injuries, such as burst fractures, which are common in high-energy trauma. NCCT also allows for the evaluation of the spinal canal and neural foramina, which can help in assessing potential neurological complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. USG (Ultrasonography). USG is not suitable for spinal injuries due to its poor penetration through bone.

 

Option B. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging). While MRI excellently delineates soft tissue and spinal cord injuries, it's not typically the initial test for acute bony trauma.

 

Option D. X-RAY. While X-rays can reveal some fractures, they may not provide the necessary detail to assess the full extent of a burst fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NCCT is the preferred initial imaging study for a suspected burst fracture due to its rapid, detailed visualization of bony injuries and the spinal canal, essential in the setting of high-energy trauma.

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 834

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced CT
Diffusion-weighted MRI
Non-contrast CT

questions.text: A 23-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a head injury following an RTA. What is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Non-contrast CT

 

Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice to identify acute intracranial bleeding and hence, is the preliminary investigation in acute head injury.

choices.text: Silver nitrate
Silver carbonate
Silver sulfate

questions.text: Which is the most common active ingredient used in conventional X-ray film?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Silver bromide

 

Option D.

 

The conventional method of screen-film radiography involves the use of X-ray film coated with a photosensitive emulsion containing silver bromide and silver iodide on both sides.

 

  • In mammography, only one side of the film is coated.
  • X-ray films exhibit the highest sensitivity to blue light and the lowest sensitivity to red light, which is why a red safe light is used in the darkroom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common active ingredient in conventional X-ray film is Silver Bromide, used in the photosensitive emulsion coating on both sides of the film, with mammography film typically coated on one side, and this composition is highly sensitive to blue light while being least sensitive to red light.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 222

choices.text: When electron beam reacts with the electromagnetic field
When electron beam strikes the cathode
When electron beam decelerates close to the nucleus of the atom in the anode
When electron beam strikes the nucleus of the atom in the anode

questions.text: Which process accurately describes the production of X-rays in an X-ray tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. When electron beam decelerates close to the nucleus of the atom in the anode

 

Option C.

 

X-rays are generated by the deceleration of an electron beam near the nucleus of the atom in the anode.

 

 

 

When electrons interact with the atoms of the anode, which can happen in two ways: -

 

  1. A fast-moving electron can interact with the atomic nucleus, resulting in continuous spectrum radiation, also known as Bremsstrahlung reaction (80%)

or

  1. It can interact with an inner shell of an atom, producing characteristic spectrum radiation (20%).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-rays are primarily generated when an electron beam decelerates near the atomic nucleus within the anode, producing Bremsstrahlung radiation.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 222

questions.text: Ultrasonography relies on which effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Piezoelectric effect

 

Option B.

 

In ultrasound imaging, a piezoelectric crystal is used to produce sound waves that are directed into the body. When an electrical current is applied to the crystal, it vibrates at a high frequency, creating sound waves that travel through the body. As the sound waves encounter different tissues and structures in the body, they are reflected back to the crystal, which then converts them into electrical signals. These signals are processed by a computer and used to create images of the internal structures of the body.

 

Piezoelectric crystals- Made up of Pb Zirconate titanate (PZT)

 

Piezoelectric effect is the ability of certain materials to generate an electric charge in response to applied mechanical stress.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Paramagnetic effect – This effect occurs in materials that are weakly attracted to a magnetic field.

 

Option C. Photoelectric effect – This effect involves the emission of electrons from a material when light shines on it.

 

Option D. Diamagnetic effect – This occurs in materials that create a magnetic field in opposition to an externally applied magnetic field.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ultrasonography uses the piezoelectric effect, where piezoelectric crystals generate sound waves that travel through the body and reflect back to create images.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

choices.text: Isointense- Hypointense - Hypointense

questions.text: What is the appearance of CSF on T1 weight MRI-T2 weighted MRI -FLAIR respectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypointense -Hyperintense-Hypointense

 

Explanation:

 

MRI sequences are essential tools for distinguishing between different types of tissue based on their appearance under various imaging conditions:

  • T1-weighted images: CSF appears hypointense (dark) compared to the brain parenchyma. White matter appears hyperintense (bright) relative to gray matter.
  • T2-weighted images: CSF appears hyperintense (bright) as it contains a high amount of water. Conversely, white matter appears hypointense compared to gray matter.
  • FLAIR (Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery): CSF signal is suppressed, making it appear hypointense (dark), which helps to detect lesions, such as those caused by demyelination, edema, or infarction, which may appear hyperintense (bright).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the signal characteristics of CSF across different MRI sequences is fundamental for interpreting brain images. CSF is typically dark on T1-weighted images, bright on T2-weighted images, and dark again on FLAIR images due to the suppression of the fluid signal to better detect pathology.

 

MRI SEQUENCES

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who is breastfeeding her 2-month-old infant presents to the clinic with a painful, red, and swollen lump in her right breast. She reports having a fever and feeling unwell for the past 24 hours. On examination, there is a tender, fluctuant mass in the upper outer quadrant of breast. What will be the next best investigation to evaluate this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans C. USG

 

Option C.

 

Ultrasonography (USG) is the best investigation of choice in lactating women who present with a breast lump where the primary suspicion is that of a breast abscess.

 

USG is preferred in pregnant women, lactating women, and young women (less than 35 years) over mammography due to dense breasts.

 

USG is the investigation of choice to distinguish solid and cystic lesions.

 

Ideal for evaluating breast lumps in lactating women to differentiate between solid and cystic masses and identify abscesses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mammogram – Typically used for routine breast screening, but can be limited by the increased breast density in lactating women.

 

Option B. Breast MRI – Provides detailed images, useful for complex cases, but not first-line due to cost and availability.

 

Option D. CT – Offers detailed cross-sectional images but is not typically used for initial evaluation of breast lumps due to less detail in soft tissue contrast compared to USG and MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ultrasound is the investigation of choice for a lactating woman presenting with a painful breast lump, providing a quick and detailed assessment to distinguish between solid and cystic lesions and identify an abscess.

 

Ref: Page no-676, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)
